hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the DataFrame. You need to identify the current column names that need to be renamed. The columns you will be working with are 'id', 'first', 'last', and 'age'.
Think about how you can rename columns in a DataFrame. Most data manipulation libraries provide a method or function to rename columns. For example, in pandas, you can use the `rename()` method.
When renaming columns, you'll need to provide a mapping of old names to new names. Consider using a dictionary where keys are the current column names and values are the new column names.

Make sure to match the new names exactly as specified in the problem statement. For instance, 'id' should be renamed to 'student_id', 'first' to 'first_name', 'last' to 'last_name', and 'age' to 'age_in_years'.
Before applying the renaming, ensure that the DataFrame is correctly loaded and structured as per the input format provided in the problem statement.
After renaming the columns, check the DataFrame to confirm that the changes have been applied correctly. You can print the DataFrame or check its columns attribute.
Consider edge cases where the DataFrame might be empty. How will your renaming logic handle an empty DataFrame? Ensure that your code does not throw errors in such scenarios.
Remember that the output format of the DataFrame should match the example provided. This means you should not only rename the columns but also ensure the data remains intact.
You might want to explore the `inplace` parameter in the renaming function. This can help you decide whether to modify the existing DataFrame or create a new one with the renamed columns.
Finally, implement the renaming logic using the method you've identified. Ensure to test your solution with the provided sample test case to verify its correctness.
